summary: “What are you doing here?” Sandor growled at the two women in front of him.   “You weren’t picking up your phone.” Sansa said...
caption:
“What are you doing here?” Sandor growled at the two women in front of him. 

“You weren’t picking up your phone.” Sansa said looking put out. 

“Yeah! How were we supposed to know you went to the movies? You could have decided to start the apocalypse or something.” Arya said earning herself a glare from her sister. Sandor may still have trouble with phones, but Arya had yet to figure out that there were more people around than there used to be and more of a need for her to keep her mouth shut. 

modern Gods/Goddess Au- Sandor (Simargl), Sansa (the morning star/Zorya Utrennyaya), and Arya (the evening star/Zorya Vechernyaya) share a house in the modern world and high-jinks ensue

summary:
Arya had loved nothing better than to sit at her father's table and listen to them talk.  

After that it was back to scrubbing...
body:
Arya had loved nothing better than to sit at her father’s table and listen to them talk. 

After that it was back to scrubbing and scurrying and listening at doors.

Listening to the talk as she went about her work, Arya had learned that Robb had won some great victory in the west.

Arya sipped at the cup of watered wine the red-haired woman had allowed her, listening. Across the square the dead men were rotting in their crow cages, but inside the Peach everyone was jolly. Except it seemed to her that some of them were laughing too hard, somehow.

Without a common language, Arya had no way of talking to the others. She listened to them, though, and repeated the words she heard to herself as she went about her work.

this post is just to say arya is very often quiet and observant when people are talking. thats all.

Hey, you can call me Mindset, or Butterfly.

Note to ASOIAF fandom followers: I've read all the books, and rarely if ever cut for spoilers, sorry. Please check my FAQ and the other links on my sidebar for more info.

summary: How progressive is the North about gender roles and women's rights? I've seen speculations that Arya's difficulties are caused...
question: How progressive is the North about gender roles and women's rights? I've seen speculations that Arya's difficulties are caused by the restrictive views on gender roles brought to Winterfell by her southron mother and her life would be very different if Ned had married a northern lady. It sounds like bullshit to me, but I'm not a book reader, only a show watcher.
answer:
It’s pretty bullshit, yeah. The North is… not exactly spectacular re gender roles and women’s rights. There is some good, mind you. The Mormont ladies are warrior women, but they pretty much have to be, due to their harsh climate and fear of raids from the ironborn. Possibly some of the mountain clans and far north houses (e.g. Umber) may raise their women similar to wildling spearwives, due to the fact they’re basically the same ethnicity and culture as the wildlings, and also to defend themselves from being kidnapped by wildling men. And we know that the Starks’ great-grandmother, Arya Flint of the mountain clans, is the reason why Bran was so good at climbing per Old Nan.

But in general? No, it’s not progressive at all. House Stark has never had a ruling Lady of Winterfell or Queen in the North in all its 8000 years of existence. And there’s two examples we know for certain where that was deliberately removed as a possibility:

  • the possibly legendary Brandon Stark “the Daughterless”, whose only child, the “Blue Rose of Winterfell”, was kidnapped by the wildling Bael the Bard (but they supposedly fell in love), and her son became the next Lord Stark
  • the situations of Serena and Sansa Stark, daughters and only children of the eldest son of Cregan Stark… and after he died, it seems likely they were forcefully married to their half-uncles so that they could steal the inheritance from them, with other inheritance problems following afterwards.

Though, to be fair, there have been other ruling ladies in a few other Northern houses (currently Jonelle Cerwyn and Lyessa Flint at least), and Winterfell women have served as the equivalent of regents at some points. Ned intended Catelyn to rule Winterfell while he was in King’s Landing, that she would train Robb to rule and make him part of her councils (but unfortunately Bran’s accident kept her from doing so). And apparently there’s a story regarding “the She-Wolves of Winterfell”, a group of fierce Stark ladies (wives, widows, mothers, and grandmothers), who may have ruled Winterfell during a time when Lord Beron Stark was dying of wounds taken while fighting the ironborn. (GRRM intended for this unfinished Dunk & Egg story to be part of the Dangerous Women anthology, but unfortunately he couldn’t finish it in time and they used an excerpt from his Fire & Blood writings instead.)

And there are certainly fierce northern ladies, who aren’t warriors like the Mormonts, but do their best to defend their rights for the dignity of their house and their loyalty to House Stark, such as Alys Karstark and Wylla Manderly. Alys fled to the Wall to prevent an unwanted marriage from her scheming uncles (who were planning on selling out her older brother to the Lannisters and Stannis to the Boltons); and Wylla bravely defended Robb’s memory and the Manderly history of loyalty, despite her supposedly Lannister/Bolton-loyal grandfather and her Frey betrothed. (She didn’t know her grandfather had secret plans to deal with the Freys and Boltons, but had a honest and fierce reaction regardless; also note her older sister Wynafryd, who was told the plans, but had to pretend to go along with everything including pretending to be happy about her own upcoming Frey marriage.) And of course there’s Lyanna Stark, who at 14 defended her father’s bannerman, young Howland Reed, from being assaulted by asshole bigots, and acted in disguise as a mystery knight to further chastise them.

However… when it comes down to it, and specifically regarding the recent generations of House Stark, let me give you these quotes:

Q: How closely does Westeros resemble the real Middle Ages in terms of social customs and gender roles? For example, would highborn ladies have been expected to bathe guests and know how to make cheese, etc.? Sansa’s education and training seemed rather impractical - did the fault lie with her parents or were all young ladies raised like that?

GRRM: Sansa is more than just a young lady.  She’s the daughter, not just of a noble, but of one of the most powerful nobles in Westeros.  The great houses stand far above the lesser nobles, as the lesser nobles do above the smallfolk. She would not make cheese, no. But Arya might think it would be fun.

–source

“Lyanna might have carried a sword, if my lord father had allowed it.”
–Ned Stark, AGOT, Arya II

[Bran’s weirwood vision of the past, of Lyanna and Benjen:] Now two children danced across the godswood, hooting at one another as they dueled with broken branches. The girl was the older and taller of the two. Arya! Bran thought eagerly, as he watched her leap up onto a rock and cut at the boy. But that couldn’t be right. If the girl was Arya, the boy was Bran himself, and he had never worn his hair so long. And Arya never beat me playing swords, the way that girl is beating him. She slashed the boy across his thigh, so hard that his leg went out from under him and he fell into the pool and began to splash and shout. “You be quiet, stupid,” the girl said, tossing her own branch aside. “It’s just water. Do you want Old Nan to hear and run tell Father?” –ADWD, Bran III

“[I]t is past time that Arya learned the ways of a southron court. In a few years she will be of an age to marry too.” –Ned Stark, AGOT, Catelyn II

“[Bran] was going to be a knight,” Arya was saying now. “A knight of the Kingsguard. Can he still be a knight?”
“No,” Ned said. He saw no use in lying to her. “Yet someday he may be the lord of a great holdfast and sit on the king’s council. He might raise castles like Brandon the Builder, or sail a ship across the Sunset Sea, or enter your mother’s Faith and become the High Septon.” But he will never run beside his wolf again, he thought with a sadness too deep for words, or lie with a woman, or hold his own son in his arms.
Arya cocked her head to one side. “Can I be a king’s councillor and build castles and become the High Septon?”
“You,” Ned said, kissing her lightly on the brow, “will marry a king and rule his castle, and your sons will be knights and princes and lords and, yes, perhaps even a High Septon.”

–AGOT, Eddard V

It’s not Catelyn with the restrictive views of gender roles. It’s the men of House Stark. I hope that helps!

Do you want Old Nan to hear and run tell Father?” –ADWD, Bran III

“[I]t is past time that Arya learned the ways of a southron court. In a few years she will be of an age to marry too.” –Ned Stark, AGOT, Catelyn II

“[Bran] was going to be a knight,” Arya was saying now. “A knight of the Kingsguard. Can he still be a knight?”
“No,” Ned said. He saw no use in lying to her. “Yet someday he may be the lord of a great holdfast and sit on the king’s council. He might raise castles like Brandon the Builder, or sail a ship across the Sunset Sea, or enter your mother’s Faith and become the High Septon.” But he will never run beside his wolf again, he thought with a sadness too deep for words, or lie with a woman, or hold his own son in his arms.
Arya cocked her head to one side. “Can I be a king’s councillor and build castles and become the High Septon?”
“You,” Ned said, kissing her lightly on the brow, “will marry a king and rule his castle, and your sons will be knights and princes and lords and, yes, perhaps even a High Septon.”

–AGOT, Eddard V

It’s not Catelyn with the restrictive views of gender roles. It’s the men of House Stark. I hope that helps!

title: David Nutter talking about Arya/Maisie:
body:
Q: What’s your favorite scene or arc of the GoT series so far?

David: Wow…It’s interesting, I’ve loved working with all the actors. It’s been interesting that Arya/Maisie and Sophie/Sansa, they’ve grown up so much during the episodes that I’ve worked with them, of course being younger actresses and characters, then now being able to be the powerful players that they are. But that’s been a wonderful experience getting the chance to work with them and see them grow and become tremendous actors, performers, and characters. That’s been a lot of fun. But I also enjoy, of course, the world with the wildlings and Jon Snow. That’s a lot of fun as well, so I have a lot of favorite moments, just being there is a special thing.

Q: What was your funniest moment while Filming Game Of Thrones??

David: I’ve enjoyed working with the Hound and Arya. They have some great duo sequences together, that’s been fun. I love working with Tormund and the Wildings. That’s been fun as well. I think that probably Arya and the Hound and their journey to the north was interesting stuff that was done there and was a lot of fun.

summary: I know you’ve stopped writing metas but I was wondering what you were expecting from s8 especially with jon x arya? I’m worried...
question: I know you’ve stopped writing metas but I was wondering what you were expecting from s8 especially with jon x arya? I’m worried they’ll ruin it for drama reasons or whatever
answer:
Honestly, I’m not as invested in the show as I used to be. S7 had its strong points, but I was overall disappointed with the characterisation, especially with the Starks. (What they did to Bran is blasphemy, my boy didn’t deserve that.)

I’m pretty much just watching because hey, new material and a lot of curiosity since I’ve dedicated almost a decade of my life to this. Damn if I don’t see it through to the end.

So my expectations for S8 are quite low. There’s obviously going to be Cersei’s betrayal of her promise, drama for about five hot minutes for Jon’s parentage, potential new Targ baby, and lots of battles with the Lannisters and the Night King.

Regarding Jon and Arya - I’m very unsure. The thing is, Arya is George’s favourite but she’s clearly not D&D’s so while I do believe the show is broadly going to end the same way as the books, I fail to see it in the case for Arya. With no Lady Stoneheart, no fake Arya, no warging with Nymeria, Arya’s story has been so watered down, I just can’t see how it’ll end the same way in the books and on the show. Sailing west while her pack lives is literally one of the lamest, most simplistic ways of ending her story because you couldn’t be asked to develop it properly.

So with that in mind, I’ve always held the belief that should Jon and Arya both survive, they’d want to remain close to each other because hey, they miss the hell out of one another and book!Jon died for her. I’m hoping we get that in S8 at least - scenes where they clearly confide and trust each other, where they have each other’s backs etc.

If I get a fight scene with both of them in the same shot, I’ll be happy. And Arya jumping into Jon’s arms like she did in S1. That’s pretty much the extent of my expectations.

I understand your concerns. I don’t anticipate trouble between Jon and Arya because they’ve mentioned before that he’s her favourite person. The drama isn’t about Jon vs the other Starks, as much as people want to play it up. There’s a literal apocalypse on the horizon, so nah, no drama. Arya and Jon love each other, and there’s no two-way interpretation about it. So the reunion will always be lovely, I think, and I hope all their scenes after will be just so as well.

Thanks for the ask!

body:
This is what I was always talking about . Sansa who betryed to Ned stark and informed Cersei about his planns in season 1.  She told to Cersei that Ned  planned to escape from Kings Landing 

There is a very interesting detail. Nobody knows about that in North. neither Arya,Jon or …Probably Bran knows about that. Why nobody spoke about that during 7 season?
Do you remember what happened after Sansa’s action? Cersei’s people mudrered Northern people who acompaned to Ned Stark from Winterfell. There were 300  man…
There is very special detail. who Knows about Sansas betrayal action? there is only 3 character stil alive: Cersei,Tyrion and Varys.
Tyrion and Varys are #TeamDany. Cersei is their enemy. 
she wants to break Stark house. what is the best maner for that?Tell the Starks that Sansa betrayed their father and he became a prissioner because of Sansa. 
look at this scene where Cersei meet to Jon 

is Cersei teling about Sansa to Jon?
Look at this season 8 teaser. there is very special detail’s from Ned Stark’s execution. There is two scene from Ned Starks’s death.
look …just look 

Do you remember Arya’s words to Sansa in season 7? 

ARYA: We both wanted to be other people when we were younger. You wanted to be a Queen, to sit next to a handsome Prince on the Iron Throne. I wanted to be a knight: to pick up a sword, like Father, and go off to battle. Neither of us got to be the other person, did we? The world doesn’t just let girls decide what they’re going to be. But I can, now. With the Faces, I can choose… I can become someone else. Speak in their voice, live in their skin. I could even become you.

(She mentioned Ned there too. with Sansa)

scene from season 7 where Arya read Sansa’s letter. This is letter from Cersei after Sansa informed about Ned. Why the used this detail ? 

Arya to Sansa: I would have let them to kill me before I betrayed my family …I remember you standing on that platform with Joffry and Cersei when thet dragged father to the block. I remember pretty dress you were wearing ….(Arya mentioned her father Ned Stark again.and especially his death  )

and another scene from season 8 teaser 

Arya Stark looked her father’s death

look at return of the Bran Stark in Winterfell. His meeting with Sansa. No emotion with his face. 

different from Sansa Bran hugged to Arya and Smiled 

But what happened when Bran gave a knife to Arya? He looked at Sansa exactly in this scene . 

And finaly. HBO realised season 8 posters and there is only 3 Stark :Arya,Jon and Bran. The puck survive ,but Lone wolf die …

There is no Sansa poster from House Stark. she is a lone walf and it’s fact. 

Cersei tells Jon about Sansa’s  betrayal.

And you think that someone will hear her explenation in north? 
‘‘I was a child?’‘ There were killed 300 northern men for Sansa. Ned Stark became a prisioner for her stupidity. Can you imagined Jon and Arya reaction about that?

summary:
Those
words made her sad. Syrio used to say that too, Arya remembered. He said it all
the time. Syrio Forel had taught her...
body:
Those words made her sad. Syrio used to say that too, Arya remembered. He said it all the time. Syrio Forel had taught her needlework and died for her. “I don’t want to leave.”

  “Then stay… but remember, the House of Black and White is not a home for orphans. All men must serve beneath this roof. Valar dohaeris is how we say it here. Remain if you will, but know that we shall require your obedience. At all times and in all things. If you cannot obey, you must depart.”

  “I can obey.”

Arya I ~ A Feast for Crows

oh this is going to go splendidly I bet

Those words made her sad. Syrio used to say that too, Arya remembered. He said it all the time. Syrio Forel had taught her needlework and died for her. “I don’t want to leave.”

  “Then stay… but remember, the House of Black and White is not a home for orphans. All men must serve beneath this roof. Valar dohaeris is how we say it here. Remain if you will, but know that we shall require your obedience. At all times and in all things. If you cannot obey, you must depart.”

  “I can obey.”

Arya I ~ A Feast for Crows

summary: Okay, as awesome as the scene is, why would Arya say Loyalty is what killed her father? Like, she doesn’t know about the stuff...
body:
Okay, as awesome as the scene is, why would Arya say Loyalty is what killed her father? Like, she doesn’t know about the stuff with Robert. She maybe knows the rumor about Cersi and Jamie, but I don’t think we were ever shown her figuring it out. She knows her father wasn’t a traitor, but she doesn’t know what he actually said that lead him to be beheaded. Also, even if she did, wouldn’t honor be better? How did loyalty kill him? Loyalty to who? Robert?

The scene is awesome, and Tywin’s face is great, but I don’t think loyalty actually makes sense.

summary: One day she came back [...] her hair all tangled and her clothes covered in mud, clutching a raggedy bunch of purple and green...
body:
One day she came back […] her hair all tangled and her clothes covered in mud, clutching a raggedy bunch of purple and green flowers for Father. Sansa kept hoping he would tell Arya to behave herself and act like the highborn lady she was supposed to be, but he never did, he only hugged her and thanked her for the flowers.

the journey south is a tedious, unfun experience for sansa but arya eagerly explores the land. she’s curious about the nature and picks some flowers for ned. sansa describes them as “raggedy” and looks down on arya for picking them but ned is thankful and he hugs arya. the act was a sincere gesture of love from arya to her father. like arya the flowers are untamed and dangerous with a beauty not all might be able to appreciate. but they are in their wild and natural glory. arya is also associated with oak trees which are symbols of the forest that represent strength

To the other maidens he had given white roses, but the one he plucked for her was red. “Sweet lady,” he said, “no victory is half so beautiful as you.” Sansa took the flower timidly, struck dumb by his gallantry. […] She inhaled the sweet fragrance of the rose and sat clutching it long after Ser Loras had ridden off.

arya refuses to attend but the tourney in kings landing is a magical event for sansa. she’s given a flower by a knight. red roses are the most classic representation from the plant world of love and desire. to receive this flower from loras means “everything” to sansa. but its a hollow gesture typical of court life from loras. he doesnt love sansa, forgets even giving her the rose and is attracted to men. much like sansa this sweet smelling flower has been cultivated in a garden to appeal to mankind’s aesthetic sensibilities. she’s also been associated with jonquils which are prized by society too
